title: Obituary for Carolyn Ann Hook, Bentonville, AR
summary:
Carolyn Ann (Cowan) Hook, 74, died April 13, 2020 at Circle of Life Hospice in Bentonville, Ark.
She was born in Greenville, Texas to Leroy and Frances Cowan.
Carolyn attended Lubbock Christian College and was a graduate of Harding University with a BA in Elementary Education.
She was a talented artist, painter, crafter, and interior designer with a passion for herbal foods and their efficacy for health.
A devoted Christian homemaker and minister's wife, she served as a member of the Bentonville Church of Christ for 40 years.

title: Tennessee offers 2022 Oklahoma commit
summary:

title: Halfway in, 2020 sees most January homicides in five years in Lubbock
summary:
So far, Lubbock investigators are looking into six homicides in January 2020 - the most homicides in the first month of the year in the last five years.
Ray Mendoza said random homicides are rare in Lubbock.
The homicides in 2020 appear to fall in line with the typical nature of slayings in Lubbock that Mendoza described.
Investigators believe Traylor and Shephard fought inside the club and Shephard shot Traylor and ran out of the club where he was shot.
Brown was arrested on a charge of tampering with evidence and was booked into the Lubbock County Detention Center.

title: Seeing 2020: ’Catalytic’ downtown projects to start construction, open this year
summary:
Construction will start and finish on notable redevelopment projects in downtown Lubbock in 2020, a year stakeholders are calling catalytic.
Construction on a parking garage, Municipal Court and a new police headquarters will start this year, according to a previous A-J article.
The 220,000-square-foot facility will be the home stage of Ballet Lubbock, the Lubbock Symphony Orchestra and Lubbock ISD.
LEPAA Board Chairman Tim Collins said the projects coming online this year will increase momentum in the shift back to downtown.
Looking ahead, Lubbock’s first downtown master plan is expected to be presented to the city council soon.

title: RODEO COLUMN: Dreamcatcher system provides helpful tools for competitors
summary:
It was about the innovative use of advanced technology at the recent Fort Worth Stock Show Rodeo that gave athletes a competitive edge.
Throughout Fort Worth’s renowned Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association/Women’s Professional Rodeo Association show, competitors watched replays of their rides in the contestants hospitality room from a half dozen or so different camera angles.
For years, rodeo competitors have watched replays, but not as vividly and distinctly as the Fort Worth Stock Show Rodeo offered.
But they said the system that’s been installed in Dickies Arena in Fort Worth was far more in-depth.
“You have an idea what your calf will do.”The Fort Worth rodeo organizers are on to something great very helpful to competitors and organizers of rodeos in other cities hopefully will follow their example.

Exhibitions at the Buddy Holly Center Fine Arts GalleryWest Texas Watercolor Society Winter Exhibition will be on display through January 12, 2020 in the Fine Arts Gallery.
First Friday Art Trail is a program of LHUCA (the Louise Hopkins Underwood Center for the Arts).
The First Friday Art Trail works to promote art and outreach within the community of Lubbock by providing an opportunity to enjoy fine art and entertainment.
For more information on the First Friday Art Trail, visit www.ffat.org.

title: 'Our boys are home’: Fallen first responders greeted upon return to Lubbock
summary:
Monday’s honor guard escort for Lubbock Police Officer Nicholas Reyna and Lubbock Fire Rescue Lt. Eric Hill was a solemn homecoming.
The men were escorted from the Tarrant County medical examiner’s office in Fort Worth back to the Lubbock County Medical Examiner’s Office.
Hill, 39, and Reyna, 27, both died Saturday morning while responding to a crash in hazardous weather in North Lubbock.
Emergency personnel were working on both crashes when a third vehicle crossed into the median and hit Dawson, Hill, and Reyna.
During the drive, state troopers in each county on the way escorted Hill and Reyna.

title: Lubbock to participate in the 2020 Point-in-Time Homeless Count on Jan. 23
summary:
LUBBOCK, Texas (NEWS RELEASE) – The following is a news release from the South Plains Homeless Consortium:On January 23,2020 the South Plains Homeless Consortium, in association with the Texas Homeless Network and volunteers from the community will take part in the annual Point-in-Time (PIT) Homeless Count, a coordinated effort to measure homelessness across Texas.
Our PIT Count will provide a “snapshot” of homelessness in Lubbock.
Other forms of homelessness, such as people staying temporarily with friends, are not included in a PIT Count.
Results from the PIT Count will be publically available and we will use the results of the PIT Count to improve our response to homelessness.
Contact Information:Chad Wheeler, PIT Lead Coordinator, 806-543-0526Erica Hitt, PIT Co-Coordinator, 806-939-3487(News release from the South Plains Homeless Consortium)

title: Five fatal crashes in Lubbock County so far in 2020
summary:
LUBBOCK, Texas — According to the Lubbock Police Department, there have been four deadly car crashes in Lubbock thus far in 2020.
In the county, there was one more reported deadly crash, making a total of five deadly crashes in Lubbock County thus far into the new year.
“We definitely don’t want the number of crashes that we’ve seen in the first ten days of 2020,” said Allison Matherly, Public Information Officer for the Lubbock Police Department.
In 2019, there were 51 fatal crashes within Lubbock city limits.
“Alcohol is in quite a few of our fatal crashes from 2019 in addition to failure to yield to oncoming traffic.”Lubbock PD wants to remind people to use caution while driving.

title: Ag Journal – Growing Hemp in 2020
summary:
LUBBOCK, Texas — For those eager to grow hemp in 2020 it is still not legal in Texas until the state establishes regulations that must be approved by USDA.
It is unclear at this point if producers will have an opportunity to plant hemp as an alternative crop by spring.
Panda Biotech plans to build the largest industrial hemp facility in Shallowater, Texas.
Hemp can be used for textiles, building products, paper products and bio-plastics among others.
“Whether it’s 2020 or beyond if you’re interested in growing hemp, I think you need to have your buyer identified with some sort of commitment,” Trostle said.

LUBBOCK, Texas (NEWS RELEASE) – The following is a news release from TxDOT:The Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) is set to begin a $34.3 million project in January 2020 that will make safety improvements to more than 27 miles of the I-27 corridor in Lubbock and Hale counties.
“The project will install concrete median barriers along I-27 through the city of Lubbock, from 82nd Street to Loop 461 in New Deal, and through the city of Plainview, from FM 3466 to SH 194.
The project is designed to enhance the overall safety of the roadway,” said Mike Wittie, P.E, TxDOT Lubbock Area Engineer.
Some inside lane closures are planned but I-27 mainlanes will be minimally impacted.

summary:

Briget Hyde, SNMA president and second-year TTUHSC medical student, said the organization created the event as an interactive and fun way to expose students to the field of medicine.

title: Texas Tech coach came out slinging after game
summary:
FAYETTEVILLE -- Who knew Texas Tech Coach Kliff Kingsbury would come into Fayetteville guns up and a'blazing in 2015?
With the 6-3 Mahomes running and slinging, the Razorbacks could not keep up in the shootout, won 35-24 by Texas Tech.
Kingsbury had taken exception to some things Arkansas Coach Bret Bielema said to a coaches' convention in Texas that summer and he offered them up, unbidden.
In a breakout game for the Bielema era, the Razorbacks destroyed Texas Tech 49-28 on Sept. 13, 2014, in Lubbock, Texas, behind 438 rushing yards and seven rushing touchdowns.

title: ICE sued to release medically vulnerable people from Texas facility
summary:
Flattening the curve and avoiding worst-case health outcomes for everyone involves dramatically reducing the number of people in ICE detention so they can practice social distancing at home.
“There is a long history of disease outbreaks in detention facilities,” Udall wrote.
“The conditions at detention facilities coupled with the risk factors of COVID-19 transmission create a deep public health risk to everyone entering and detained at detention facilities across the country.
Among the most at-risk individuals are employees who report to work at detention facilities and prisons and return home to their families on a daily basis.
New Mexico is home to three ICE detention centers: Cibola County Correctional Center, Torrance County Detention Facility, and Otero County Processing Center.

title: Snow down! Winter weather brings a break, but slick roads a threat around Lubbock
summary:
Lubbock saw about 1/2 inch of snow at Preston Smith International Airport by mid-day Wednesday, while much of the city saw upward of an inch, according to the National Weather Service.
Some areas in the southwestern Panhandle also saw considerable snowfall, including 5 inches at Friona and 3 inches at Muleshoe.
Lubbock Meals on Wheels did not deliver meals Wednesday, urging its clients to use the emergency winter meal kits it had distributed earlier.
The winter weather prompted Lubbock officials and first responders to activate the city‘ Emergency Operations Center Tuesday into Wednesday, with officials monitoring road conditions, power and other public safety functions.
TxDOT crews were working through the day Wednesday to plow snow from roads and treat icy bridges and overpasses, according to a statement from TxDOT.

The chase finished between Farm-to-market Road 2902 and Farm-to-market Road 1729.
The men bailed out of the car when it became disabled.
The chase spanned multiple counties, crossing into Hockley County at one point.
A DPS helicopter was called in toward the end of the chase.

summary:
Covenant’s media and community relations liaison, Meredith Cunningham, helped coordinate the visit as the Globetrotters typically visit any time they are in Lubbock.
"Usually spinning the ball on their finger is a really, really cool trick that nobody as done or really experienced," Lou said regarding his go-to trick to get a smile.
"So getting them to experience what we do on a regular basis is really, really cool and that usually lights them up."
At Covenant Children’s, Lou said he formed a quick bond with one of the patients through their one of their shared interests.
"It’s really really impactful to me."

title: 'Our season is on the line': Moretti says No. 22 Texas Tech must become more consistent following home loss to Texas
summary:
22 Texas Tech and the Longhorns, who were looking to improve their NCAA Tournament résumés, came out with intensity but the second half proved to be the difference.
Texas Tech (18-11, 9-7) suffered its third loss at home at the hands of the Longhorns (18-11, 8-8), who have won their last four games and collected back-to-back wins over Top 25 teams for the first time since the 2013-14 season.
"We expected this, this is what good teams do," Texas Tech coach Chris Bead said of Texas.
Ramsey finished 13 points, while Moretti and Terrence Shannon Jr. added 11 and 10 points, respectively, in the Red Raiders loss.
Jones led all scorers with 22 points and Ramey chipped in 12 points.

title: Lubbock house fire started in tent in backyard
summary:
LUBBOCK, Texas — Lubbock Fire Rescue responded to a house fire Sunday morning in the 1900 block of 17th Street.
“Occupants inside the residence were alerted by smoke detectors and their dog,” LFR said.
LFR said a family member was staying in a tent behind the residence.
“An extension cord running from inside the residence through a window was powering a TV and a space heater in the tent,” LFR said.
“The occupant fell asleep in the tent and awoke to a popping noise and the tent on fire.”The fire spread from the tent to the house, LFR said.

title: Sample ballots, voting locations for March 3 Primary
summary:

This allows the person to vote on races that would be on ballots in both counties.
The voter must go the Elections Office, 1308 Crickets Avenue, to fill out a form and request the Limited Ballot.
The voter will then be registered in Lubbock County.

title: Lubbock Christian school band student selected into the 2020 ATSSB All - State Band
summary:
As the oldest private school in the greater Lubbock area, Lubbock Christian School (LCS) began serving families in 1954.
The initial classes on the current campus were held in 1958, and the Class of 1965 was the first to graduate from Lubbock Christian High School.
No church governs or subsidizes Lubbock Christian School, although the school was founded and is directed by members of Churches of Christ.
The school is fully accredited through AdvancEd and the Texas Private School Accreditation Commission (TEPSAC), which is fully approved and recognized by the Texas Education Agency.
LCS welcomes families of all faiths and admits students of any race, color, and national or ethnic origin.

summary:
LUBBOCK, Texas (CITY OF LUBBOCK NEWS RELEASE) - Beginning Monday, March 30, 2020, the City of Lubbock libraries will suspend curbside service and delivery amid COVID-19 concerns.
However, the libraries will continue to provide a variety of services and materials for the citizens of Lubbock.
In addition to eBooks and audiobooks available through the Libby app, the library has a large number of resources and Texshare databases online.
Patrons can access these resources with their library card and/or their Texshare username and password.
If you do not already have a library card pin or your Texshare information, please call or email any of the four Lubbock Public Library Branches for this information.

The facility was following the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services guidelines for nursing homes, and the employees were identified through the established screening process.

title: Community spread hits Lubbock as county’s confirmed coronavirus cases reach 10
summary:
The weekend brought six new confirmed cases of the coronavirus in Lubbock County, bringing the total to 10, but there are currently no plans to have residents shelter-in-place.
While the initial cases in Lubbock were related to travel out of the country or related to exposure to a known case, two new cases appear to be the start of community spread.
Lubbock Health Authority Ron Cook commended people in the community for practicing social distancing, including in lines at the grocery stores.
"If you’ve been tested or you’re sick, do not go out into the community - you need to stay home," said Cook.
"If you’ve been tested or met the criteria to be tested, you need to stay home until that test results comes back."

"I think they have worries that adults have too.
They sense a lot that’s going on, and so just to see they’re teachers are out there caring enough to say hi and willing to show them that we’re all happy and healthy and doing great, I think that’s a good thing for them to see.”

title: South Plains COVID-19 Response Fund: Aiding Non-Profits Tackle Coronavirus Impacts
summary:
Mayor Pope says there is a specific reason these funds are directed to non-profits, which will in turn help individuals, essentially creating a trickle down effect, “Well, many times when we help a family we’re helping a business.
Much of our community are men and women who are sole proprietors.
They’re the folks that cut our hair, or mow our grass, or help us with our nails, or many times they’re the ones that work in retail in our community, or work in our restaurants and bars who’ve been furloughed or laid off.
That’s where this thing hurts the most today, that’s where we need to address the need.”

title: Texas’ largest counties are issuing stay-at-home orders as coronavirus spreads

summary:

title: Rosa’s Cafe Issues Statement After Lubbock Restaurant Potentially Exposed to COVID-19
summary:
According to Rosa's Cafe, the student was "the last customer to visit and leave the restaurant" that night.
The Rosa's Cafe location has also been closed to begin a "Level 3 cleaning."
The company said it will reopen the location only when the City of Lubbock Health Department inspects and clears it.
Rosa’s Cafe has confirmed that an individual who had previously been exposed to the coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, recently visited the Rosa’s Cafe location at 4th and Quaker in Lubbock, Texas.
The management team of the Rosa’s Cafe is placing customer and employee health as its primary concern and will not reopen the restaurant until it passes all health inspections and is cleared to reopen by the city health department.

title: Texas prisons ramp up coronavirus protection measures
summary:
As the number of infections and deaths from the new coronavirus rise across Texas, prison officials are ramping up efforts to prevent an outbreak among the state’s 140,000 inmates.
Prison hospitals will limit the number of medical students who see patients to prevent transmission possibilities.
Prison officials said that any employee with a temperature of 100.4 degrees or higher would be sent home.
The U.S. Bureau of Prisons has already implemented a number of the safety protocols Texas officials announced this week, but they have also limited movement among inmates.
TDCJ subcontracts with the University of Texas Medical Branch and Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center to provide inmates with health care.

title: Edmoundson Earns Softball America Shortened Season All-America Honors
summary:
After the close of the abbreviated 2020 softball season, junior pitcherrepresented the Texas Tech softball team with a Shortened Season Second Team All-America nod from Softball America.Finishing the season as the publication's 26-ranked player, Edmoundson made major waves in her third season with the Red Raiders.
The southpaw ended the regular season with a 10-4 record and became the second Red Raider in program history to throw a perfect game – doing so against Fairleigh Dickinson on Mar.
7.Edmoundson led the Red Raiders with 10 wins, 93 strikeouts and a .180 opponent batting average through 78.2 innings pitched.
Additionally, she ranked fourth on the team with a .300 batting average.
For all the latest information on the Texas Tech softball team, visit TexasTech.com or follow @TexasTechSB on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram.

title: State invokes eminent domain to obtain property for outer loop project
summary:
State transportation officials are going to court to obtain portions of two plots of land in the southern edge of Lubbock aimed at being part of the planned Loop 88, also known as the Outer Loop.
The state is only seeking parts of the land to make right of ways for the Outer Loop and the property owners will keep the rest of the land.
“This project is a great thing for the landowners.”The property sits in the path of the planned Outer Loop project laid out by the Lubbock Metropolitan Planning Organization’s proposed 2045 transportation plan.
The state-sponsored project to build the Outer Loop is listed as a “priority for the Texas Department of Transportation, City of Lubbock and County,” the plan states.
“This is the main corridor for growth in Lubbock and the project will increase economic development and make the corridor safer.”

title: Lubbock mayor declares public health disaster, limits public gatherings to 200 people
summary:
The City of Lubbock City Council has issued a Disaster Declaration.
This Declaration prohibits all indoor and outdoor public and private gatherings of 200 persons or more, anywhere in the City of Lubbock, beginning at 5:00 p.m. on March 17, 2020.
For all other gatherings, the Declaration strongly recommends citizens adhere to Social Distancing Protocols established by the United states Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), including canceling, rescheduling, or not attending events with more than 50 persons.

title: It’s time for Super Tuesday in Texas
summary:
Voting locations will be open from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. today as Texans take part in Super Tuesday.
Texas is one of 14 states with primary elections on March 3.
Voters choose either to vote in the Republican Primary or the Democratic Primary, but cannot vote in both.
In Lubbock County, early voting turnout in the Republican Primary more than doubled that seen in the Democratic Primary.
Through Friday, 6,160 votes had been cast in Lubbock County’s Democratic Primary, and 16,561 votes were cast in the Republican primary.

title: Two runoffs in the mix for district judge races in Lubbock
summary:
LUBBOCK, Texas — Kara L. Darnell and Phillip Hays appear to be headed for a runoff election in the Republican race for 99th District judge’s race in the March 3 Texas Primary.
Darnell had 42.35 percent in the final unofficial vote total while Hays had 30.48 percent.
May 26 is set aside by the state for the primary runoff election.
In the Republican Primary for the State District Judge in the 140th Judicial District, Douglas H. Freitag and Tom Brummett appear to be headed for a runoff.
There is no Democrat in either the 99th District race or the 140th District race.

summary:

Based on the initial investigation, Smith was arrested and taken to the Lubbock County Detention Center, according to police.
Smith was treated at a hospital and booked into the Lubbock County jail March 1.

title: Shaw wins unofficial final Republican vote in County Commissioner Precinct 3

Shaw carried 60.49 percent of the unofficial vote total.
Ysidro Gutierrez had 17.86 percent, and Victor Flores had 21.65 percent.
In November, Shaw will face the winner of the Democrat side the primary — presumably Gilbert Flores based on the unofficial final results.

Cruz received 4.2 million votes to O’Rourke’s 4 million - a surprising margin of only about 2 percentage points.

title: Local travel advisor weighs in on travel safety and coronavirus
summary:

“The biggest thing right now people are calling and asking us if should [they] cancel [their] trip,” said Lindsay Foerster, CEO of Foerster Travel.
Foerster said airlines are trying to incentivize people to travel due to a fear of traveling.
“We had some clients that were looking to go to Vegas, in the next couple of weeks,” she said.
“My biggest piece of advice for people right now is that if you have travel in the next couple of months like you’re not going next week,” said Foerster.

MEMORIALS: If desired, memorials may be made to First Baptist Church of Comanche, 407 N. Houston Street, Comanche, Texas 76442.
Charles “Butch” Gott, age 76, passed away on Friday, April 10, 2020, in Comanche, Texas.
He was born on October 31, 1943, in Brownwood, Texas, to Charlie Earl and Gladys (Cadenhead) Gott.
On December 30, 1961, he was united in marriage to Lena Sue Yarbrough in Lubbock, Texas.
He is survived by his wife, Lena Sue Gott of Comanche; son, Joshua Gott and wife Karen of Lindale; daughter, Terri Christian and husband Van of Comanche; grandchildren, Forrest Gott of Lindale, Eathan Gott and wife Hannah of Lindale; Zac Christian of Comanche, and Zeph Christian of Comanche; sister, Earlene Brown of Nampa, Idaho; and numerous cousins, nieces and nephews.

The City Manager and Mayor will present the organization’s progress toward previously stated City Council Priorities.
These priorities focused on six areas of interest: Fiscal Discipline, Communication, Community Improvement, Public Safety, Growth & Development and Economic Development & Redevelopment.

title: Raider Park sues Lubbock for $1 million or more
summary:
LUBBOCK, Texas — The owners of Raider Park Garage, an 11-story parking garage at 2522 Marsha Sharp Freeway, sued the City of Lubbock last week for $1 million or more.
The current owner is MVP Raider Park Garage LLCThe lawsuit said, “In 2012, the previous owners of Raider Park sought a variance from the City of Lubbock’s sign ordinance … This variance would allow tenants within Raider Park to install signs that covered approximately thirty-five percent of the surface area on three sides of the parking garage.”That variance was approved in October 2012 and came up for review in October 2019.
Under state law, the city needed to inform the owners of all the properties within 200 feet according to the lawsuit.
The lawsuit said the city did not notify the current owners of Raider Park, but instead the city’s Zoning Board of Adjustment sent a notice to the previous owners.
The current owners said in the lawsuit that the city denied due process and failed to meet state law.

Chief Mitchell has more than 29 years of law enforcement experience and is currently the Chief of Police for Temple, Texas, a Recognized department by the Texas Police Chief’s Association.
Mitchell served previously in Kansas City, Missouri, where he began his police career.

Chief Mitchell is a Master Certified Peace Officer in Texas and is a graduate of the FBI National Academy.

title: Ongoing Reagor Dykes debacle dominated Lubbock area business news in 2019
summary:
The ongoing legal saga - in criminal, civil and bankruptcy courts - of Reagor Dykes Auto Group topped the business news cycle in 2019, and will likely continue to through the next year.
Witnesses said Reagor Dykes was under-capitalized due to its aggressive growth and acquisitions of new dealerships.
U.S. District Judge Sam Cummings granted a summary judgment in the ongoing civil case Ford Credit v. Bart Reagor May 24, asking Reagor to pay the remainder of what Ford Credit claims it is owed.
Reagor’s former business partner Rick Dykes previously agreed in a settlement to pay $58 million to Ford.
A plan for Reagor Dykes Auto Group to exit Chapter 11 bankruptcy and reorganize into a new business is expected to be presented in bankruptcy court in January.

Inspired by Charles Schultz’s 1954 security blanket-toting character, Linus van Pelt, Project Linus has over 400 chapters in communities throughout the United States and Canada.
The only Project Linus chapter in the Panhandle of Texas, the Lubbock Chapter blanketeers have made nearly 17,000 handmade blankets to provide comfort and security to local children who have experienced trauma, tragedy or illness.
More Information:Lisa Allen, Coordinator806.790.1113(News release from the Lubbock Chapter of Project Linus)

The current state of the economy won’t factor into 2019 property tax bills, but could possibly affect appraisals for next year.

summary:
Lubbock Parks and Recreation has hosted Santa Land for the past 63 years, and admission is free.
Santa Land is open every evening from December 10-23, 2019, from 6:00 to 10:00 p.m.
Approximately 50,000 people visit Santa Land each year to see the festive holiday village with its huge lighted Christmas tree, animated displays, bonfires, traditional holiday scenes, and of course, Santa and Mrs. Claus.
Each evening at 6:00 p.m. during this 14-night event, a sleigh with tiny reindeer bring Santa and Mrs. Claus to Santa Land to hear the Christmas wishes of area children.
The entrance to Santa Land is located off of the East Broadway entrance into Mackenzie Park, east of Avenue A and the South Plains Fairgrounds.
